arguments.argument: Confederate monuments honor a history rooted in slavery and oppression.
Removing them acknowledges the harm caused by the Confederacy.
Public spaces should reflect shared values, not divisive historical figures.
Many Confederate statues were erected to uphold white supremacy, not history.
Relocating them to museums preserves history without glorifying oppression.
The U.S. should not celebrate those who fought against the Union.
Keeping these monuments sends the wrong message about racial equality.
Memorializing Confederates undermines progress toward social justice.
Other countries do not publicly celebrate those who fought to preserve injustice.
Public statues should honor unity, not division.
Confederate monuments are a part of American history, and history should not be erased.
Removing statues could set a precedent for eliminating any controversial historical figure.
They serve as educational tools to discuss the Civil War and its consequences.
Not everyone who fought for the Confederacy was fighting to uphold slavery.
Public monuments should not be removed based on contemporary political views.
Monuments should be contextualized rather than removed.
People should have the right to honor their heritage, even if controversial.
Many statues were built with public funding and should remain as historical markers.
History should be preserved, not rewritten or hidden.
Focusing on statues distracts from addressing present-day racial inequalities.
